title: Let the Music (Lift You Up)
text:
"Let the Music (Lift You Up)" is a 1994 song by British <a href="house%20music">house music</a> group <a href="Loveland%20%28band%29">Loveland</a> featuring singer <a href="Rachel%20McFarlane">Rachel McFarlane</a>, released as their debut single. It is a cover of a song by American singer Darlene Lewis and some of the single releases featured both versions. The Loveland version peaked at number 16 on the <a href="UK%20Singles%20Chart">UK Singles Chart</a>, number-one on the <a href="UK%20Dance%20Singles%20Chart">UK Dance Singles Chart</a> and won the Best Dance Record of the Year award at the <a href="Silver%20Clef%20Award">Silver Clef Award</a>. In 1995, it was included on the band's only album, "The Wonder of Love". 
Critical reception.
<a href="Larry%20Flick">Larry Flick</a> from American magazine "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>" wrote, "Virtually flawless <a href="disco">disco</a>/<a href="House%20music">house</a> number is poised to glide from atop <a href="UK%20Dance%20Singles%20Chart">U.K. dance charts</a> onto stateside dancefloors within seconds. Track pumps a heavy beat, which is tied in flowing ribbons of strings and horns. <a href="Rachel%20McFarlane">Rachel McFarlane</a> provides a bright flash of diva belting, proving her moxie by holding her own against a busy, effect-filled arrangement. Rhythm/crossover radio tastemakers are advised to open their minds and ears." Andy Beevers from "<a href="Music%20Week">Music Week</a>" deemed it a "huge house track from <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a>". He added, "The Full On Vocal Mix, with its pounding pianos and hackneyed lyrics, is undeniably old-fashioned and is about as cheesy as a lorryload of <a href="Wotsits">Wotsits</a>. But it comes with a guarantee to create absolute mayhem on all but the most elite of dancefloors." <a href="James%20Hamilton%20%28DJ%20and%20journalist%29">James Hamilton</a> from the magazine's "RM" Dance Update said that the Loveland cover version of the Darlene Lewis song is "much more exciting". 
References.
